permit2/overview.title: Overview
permit2/overview.description: Permit2 is a unification of 2 contracts, SignatureTransfer and AllowanceTransfer. The SignatureTransfer contract handles all signature-based transfers, meaning that an allowance on the token is bypassed and permissions to the spender only last for the duration of the transaction that the one-time signature is spent. The AllowanceTransfer contract handles setting allowances on tokens, giving permissions to spenders on a specified amount for a specified duration of time. Any transfers that then happen through the AllowanceTransfer contract will only succeed if the proper permissions have been set.

universal-router/overview.title: Overview
universal-router/overview.description: The UniversalRouter is an ETH, ERC20, and NFT swap router, that can aggregate trades across protocols to give users access highly-flexible and personalised transactions. The contract is unowned, and is not upgradeable.

v1/concepts/advanced-topics/math.title: Math
v1/concepts/advanced-topics/math.description: This section will be expanded in the future. In the mean time, the Uniswap V2 whitepaper has most relevant math for Jingo V1.

v1/concepts/advanced-topics/pricing.title: Pricing
v1/concepts/advanced-topics/pricing.description: As we learned in Protocol Overview, each pair on Jingo is actually underpinned by a liquidity pool. Liquidity pools are smart contracts that hold balances of two unique tokens and enforces rules around depositing and withdrawing them. The primary rule is the constant product formula. When a token is withdrawn (bought), a proportional amount must be deposited (sold) to maintain the constant. The ratio of tokens in the pool, in combination with the constant product formula, ultimately determine the price that a swap executes at.

v1/concepts/advanced-topics/research.title: Research
v1/concepts/advanced-topics/research.description: The automated market maker is a new concept, and as such, new research comes out frequently. We've selected some of the most thoughtful here.

v1/concepts/advanced-topics/security.title: Security
v1/concepts/advanced-topics/security.description: Between January 8 and April 30, a team of six engineers reviewed and formally verified crucial components of the smart contracts for Jingo V1.

v1/concepts/advanced-topics/understandin.title: Understanding Returns
v1/concepts/advanced-topics/understandin.description: Jingo incentivizes users to add liquidity to trading pools by rewarding providers with the fees generated when other users trade with those pools. Market making, in general, is a complex activity. There is a risk of losing money during large and sustained movement in the underlying asset price compared to simply holding an asset.

v1/concepts/core-concepts/flash-swaps.title: Flash Swaps
v1/concepts/core-concepts/flash-swaps.description: Jingo flash swapsallow you to withdraw up to the full reserves of any ERC20 token on Jingo and execute arbitrary logic at no upfront cost, provided that by the end of the transaction you either:

v1/concepts/core-concepts/oracles.title: Oracles
v1/concepts/core-concepts/oracles.description: A price oracle is any tool used to view price information about a given asset. When you look at stock prices on your phone, you are using your phone as a price oracle. Similarly, the app on your phone relies on devices to retrieve price information - likely several, which are aggregated and then displayed to you, the end-user. These are price oracles as well.

v1/concepts/core-concepts/pools.title: Pools
v1/concepts/core-concepts/pools.description: Each Jingo liquidity pool is a trading venue for a pair of ERC20 tokens. When a pool contract is created, its balances of each token are 0; in order for the pool to begin facilitating trades, someone must seed it with an initial deposit of each token. This first liquidity provider is the one who sets the initial price of the pool. They are incentivized to deposit an equal value of both tokens into the pool. To see why, consider the case where the first liquidity provider deposits tokens at a ratio different from the current market rate. This immediately creates a profitable arbitrage opportunity, which is likely to be taken by an external party.

v1/concepts/core-concepts/swaps.title: Swaps
v1/concepts/core-concepts/swaps.description: Token swaps in Jingo are a simple way to trade one ERC-20 token for another.

v1/concepts/protocol-overview/ecosystem-.title: Ecosystem Participants
v1/concepts/protocol-overview/ecosystem-.description: The Jingo ecosystem is primarily comprised of three types of users: liquidity providers, traders, and developers. Liquidity providers are incentivized to contribute ERC-20 tokens to common liquidity pools. Traders can swap these tokens for one another for a fixed 0.30% fee (which goes to liquidity providers). Developers can integrate directly with Jingo smart contracts to power new and exciting interactions with tokens, trading interfaces, retail experiences, and more.

v1/concepts/protocol-overview/how-jingo-.title: How Jingo works
v1/concepts/protocol-overview/how-jingo-.description: Jingo is an automated liquidity protocol powered by a constant product formula

v1/concepts/protocol-overview/smart-cont.title: Smart contracts
v1/concepts/protocol-overview/smart-cont.description: Jingo V1 is a binary smart contract system. Core contracts provide fundamental safety guarantees for all parties interacting with Jingo. Periphery contracts interact with one or more core contracts but are not themselves part of the core.

v1/guides/interface-integration/custom-i.title: Custom Linking
v1/guides/interface-integration/custom-i.description: The Jingo front-end supports URL query parameters to allow for custom linking to the Jingo frontend. Users and developers can use these query parameters to link to the Jingo frontend with custom prefilled settings.

v1/guides/interface-integration/iframe-i.title: Iframe Integration
v1/guides/interface-integration/iframe-i.description: These docs are deprecated. Please refer to Swap Widget to embed the Jingo swap widget as a React component in your website in 2 minutes.

v1/guides/interface-integration/using-th.title: Using the API
v1/guides/interface-integration/using-th.description: In this guide we will create a web interface that consumes and displays data from the Jingo Subgraph. The goal is to provide a quick overview of a setup that you can extend to create your own UIs and analytics around Jingo data.

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/bui.title: Building an Oracle
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/bui.description: To build a price oracle on Jingo V1, you must first understand the

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/get.title: Pair Addresses
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/get.description: The most obvious way to get the address for a pair is to call getPair on the factory. If the pair exists, this function will return its address, else address(0) (0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000).

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/qui.title: Smart Contract Quick start
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/qui.description: Developing smart contracts for Ethereum involves a bevy of off-chain tools used for producing and testing bytecode

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/sup.title: Supporting meta transactions
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/sup.description: All Jingo V1 pool tokens support meta-transaction approvals via the permit function. This obviates the need for a blocking approve transaction before programmatic interactions with pool tokens can occur.

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/tra.title: Implement a Swap
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/tra.description: When trading from a smart contract, the most important thing to keep in mind is that access to an external price source is required. Without this, trades can be frontrun for considerable loss.

v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/usi.title: Flash Swaps
v1/guides/smart-contract-integration/usi.description: Flash swaps are an integral feature of Jingo V1. In fact, under the hood, all swaps are actually flash swaps! This simply means that pair contracts send output tokens to the recipient before enforcing that enough input tokens have been received. This is slightly atypical, as one might expect a pair to ensure it's received payment before delivery. However, because Ethereum transactions are atomic, we can roll back the entire swap if it turns out that the contract hasn't received enough tokens to make itself whole by the end of the transaction.

v1/overview.title: Overview
v1/overview.description: Welcome to the Jingo protocol V1 docs.

v1/reference/API/entities.title: Entities
v1/reference/API/entities.description: Entities define the schema of the subgraph, and represent the data that can be queried. Within each entity are sets of fields that store useful information related to the entity. Below is a list of the available entities within the Jingo Subgraph, and descriptions for the available fields.

v1/reference/API/overview.title: API Overview
v1/reference/API/overview.description: This section explains the Jingo Subgraph and how to interact with it. The Jingo subgraph indexes data from the Jingo contracts over time. It organizes data about pairs, tokens, Jingo as a whole, and more. The subgraph updates any time a transaction is made on Jingo. The subgraph runs on The Graph protocol's hosted service and can be openly queried.

v1/reference/API/queries.title: Queries
v1/reference/API/queries.description: The subgraph can be queried to retrieve important information about Jingo, pairs, tokens, transactions, users, and more. This page will provide examples for common queries.

v1/reference/Governance/governance-refer.title: Governance Reference
v1/reference/Governance/governance-refer.description: The updated reference for the newly deployed Governor Bravo is available via Etherscan, some of the reference material below may be out of date.

v1/reference/smart-contracts/common-erro.title: Common Errors
v1/reference/smart-contracts/common-erro.description: This document covers a few error codes frequently encountered while building on Jingo V1.

v1/reference/smart-contracts/pair.title: Pair
v1/reference/smart-contracts/pair.description: This documentation covers Jingo-specific functionality. For ERC-20 functionality, see Pair (ERC-20).

v1/reference/smart-contracts/Pair-ERC-20.title: Pair (ERC-20)
v1/reference/smart-contracts/Pair-ERC-20.description: This documentation covers ERC-20 functionality for denominating pool tokens. For Jingo-specific functionality, see Pair.

v1/reference/smart-contracts/router-01.title: Router01
v1/reference/smart-contracts/router-01.description: JingoV1Router01 should not be used any longer, because of the discovery of a low severity bug and the fact that some methods do not work with tokens that take fees on transfer. The current recommendation is to use JingoV1Router02.

v1/reference/smart-contracts/router-02.title: Router02
v1/reference/smart-contracts/router-02.description: Because routers are stateless and do not hold token balances, they can be replaced safely and trustlessly, if necessary. This may happen if more efficient smart contract patterns are discovered, or if additional functionality is desired. For this reason, routers have release numbers, starting at 01. This is currently recommended release, 02.

v2/guides/flash-integrations/inheritance.title: Getting Started
v2/guides/flash-integrations/inheritance.description: In this guide, we will write a smart contract that calls flash on a V3 pool and swaps the full amount withdrawn of token0 and token1 in the corresponding pools with the same token pair - but different fee tiers. After the swap, the contract will pay back the first pool and transfer profits to the original calling address.

v2/guides/local-environment.title: Set Up Your Local Environment
v2/guides/local-environment.description: One of the most common questions we get asked is what development toolset to use to build on-chain integrations with Uniswap. Theres no right answer to this question but for this guide well recommend a common one: Node.js , NPM and Hardhat.

v2/guides/providing-liquidity/decrease-l.title: Decrease Liquidity
v2/guides/providing-liquidity/decrease-l.description: Make sure to go through the Setting Up Your Contract before continuing to this section

v2/guides/providing-liquidity/increase-l.title: Increase Liquidity
v2/guides/providing-liquidity/increase-l.description: Increase Liquidity Within The Current Range

v2/guides/providing-liquidity/the-full-c.title: The Full Contract
v2/guides/providing-liquidity/the-full-c.description: Below we have the complete functioning code example: a contract that can custody Jingo V3 position NFT's and manipulate the positions and liquidity therein by collecting fees, increasing or decreasing liquidity, and minting new positions. View on github here.

v2/guides/swaps/single-swaps.title: Single Swaps
v2/guides/swaps/single-swaps.description: Swaps are the most common interaction with the Jingo protocol. The following example shows you how to implement a single-path swap contract that uses two functions that you create:

v2/overview.title: Overview

v2/reference/core/libraries/BitMath.description: This library provides functionality for computing bit properties of an unsigned integer

v2/reference/core/libraries/TransferHelp.title: TransferHelper
v2/reference/core/libraries/TransferHelp.description: Contains helper methods for interacting with ERC20 tokens that do not consistently return true/false

v2/reference/deployments.title: Deployment Addresses
v2/reference/deployments.description: The latest version of @jingofi/v3-core, @jingofi/v3-periphery, @jingofi/swap-router-contracts, and @jingofi/v3-staker are deployed at the addresses listed below. Integrators should no longer assume that they are deployed to the same addresses across chains and be extremely careful to confirm mappings below.

v2/reference/overview.description: Jingo V3 is a binary smart contract system comprised of many libraries, which together make the Core and Periphery.
